title: Ezekiel Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 5.

questions.question: What was Ezekiel instructed to use on his head and beard in Ezekiel 5:1?
options: A sharp knife and a barber's razor
A sword and a shield
A bowl of water and oil
A crown and a robe
questions.correctAnswer: A sharp knife and a barber's razor
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:1 commands the son of man to take a sharp knife and a barber's razor and cause it to pass upon his head and beard.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 5:2, what will happen to a third part of the hair?
options: It shall be burned with fire in the city
It shall be buried in the ground
It shall be given as an offering
It shall be woven into a garment
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be burned with fire in the city
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:2 states that a third part of the hair will be burned with fire in the midst of the city after the siege.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 5:3, what does Ezekiel do with a few hairs?
options: Bind them in his skirts
Plant them in the soil
Throw them into the river
Hide them in a box
questions.correctAnswer: Bind them in his skirts
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:3 tells Ezekiel to take a few hairs and bind them in his skirts.

questions.question: What will come forth into all the house of Israel as described in Ezekiel 5:4?
options: A fire
A flood
A wind
A plague
questions.correctAnswer: A fire
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:4 states that a fire will come forth into all the house of Israel.

questions.question: Where has the Lord set Jerusalem according to Ezekiel 5:5?
options: In the midst of the nations and countries around her
By the sea
In the desert
On a mountain alone
questions.correctAnswer: In the midst of the nations and countries around her
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:5 says the Lord set Jerusalem in the midst of the nations and countries around her.

questions.question: Why has Jerusalem changed God's judgments into wickedness as stated in Ezekiel 5:6?
options: Because they refused His judgments and statutes
Because they built many temples
Because they worshiped idols only
Because they were victorious in battle
questions.correctAnswer: Because they refused His judgments and statutes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:6 explains that Jerusalem changed God's judgments into wickedness because they refused His judgments and statutes.

questions.question: What is the Lord's stance toward Jerusalem in Ezekiel 5:8?
options: He is against her and will execute judgments in her midst
He will protect her from all enemies
He will bless her with peace
He will lead her to prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: He is against her and will execute judgments in her midst
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:8 clearly states that the Lord is against Jerusalem and will execute judgments in her midst.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 5:10, what dreadful act will occur among the people?
options: Fathers shall eat their sons and sons shall eat their fathers
They will all flee to the mountains
They will build a great wall
They will fast for many days
questions.correctAnswer: Fathers shall eat their sons and sons shall eat their fathers
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:10 describes that fathers will eat their sons and sons will eat their fathers as part of the judgment.

questions.question: What will happen to the sanctuary because of the abominations, as stated in Ezekiel 5:11?
options: It will be defiled and the Lord will diminish Jerusalem
It will be rebuilt
It will be filled with peace
It will be hidden from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: It will be defiled and the Lord will diminish Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:11 says that because the sanctuary was defiled with abominations, the Lord will diminish Jerusalem.

questions.question: How are the people of Jerusalem divided in Ezekiel 5:12 regarding their fate?
options: A third will die by pestilence and famine, a third by the sword, and a third will be scattered
All will be taken captive
All will be spared
Half will be punished and half will be saved
questions.correctAnswer: A third will die by pestilence and famine, a third by the sword, and a third will be scattered
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:12 divides the people into three parts: one dies by pestilence and famine, one by the sword, and one is scattered.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 5:7 states that Jerusalem walked in God's statutes.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:7 states that Jerusalem has not walked in God's statutes.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 5:13, the Lord will be comforted after accomplishing His fury upon Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:13 says the Lord will be comforted after His fury is accomplished upon them.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 5:9 says the Lord will do something He has never done before because of Jerusalem's abominations.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:9 declares that the Lord will do what He has not done before due to their abominations.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezekiel 5:14: 'Moreover I will make thee waste, and a ______ among the nations that are round about thee.'
options: reproach
king
leader
friend
questions.correctAnswer: reproach
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:14 states that the Lord will make Jerusalem a reproach among the nations.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 5:15, Jerusalem will be an ______ and an astonishment to the nations.
options: instruction
enemy
ally
kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: instruction
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:15 describes Jerusalem as an instruction and an astonishment to the nations.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with obedience to God's commands. Based on Ezekiel 5, what biblical truth would you share about consequences of disobedience?
options: Disobedience leads to judgments and scattering among nations
God ignores disobedience and allows everything to continue
Obedience has no impact on life circumstances
God rewards disobedience with blessings
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience leads to judgments and scattering among nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:6-12 shows that because Israel did not walk in God's statutes and judgments, God executed judgments including death, famine, sword, and scattering the remnant among the nations.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 5 teach us about trusting God's discipline during trials?
options: God’s discipline is a sign of His zeal and purpose for correction
God punishes without reason or care
God’s discipline is random and not connected to sin
God never disciplines His people
questions.correctAnswer: God’s discipline is a sign of His zeal and purpose for correction
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:13 states God’s anger and fury will be accomplished so that they know the Lord has spoken in zeal, showing discipline has purpose in God's plan.

questions.question: In the context of spiritual discipline, what does the shaving and dividing of hair symbolize in Ezekiel 5?
options: Judgment dividing the people into portions of destruction, death, and scattering
A ritual for purification
A symbol of victory and blessing
An act of celebration
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment dividing the people into portions of destruction, death, and scattering
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:1-2 describes the shaving and dividing of hair into thirds: burning, striking with the knife, and scattering by the wind, symbolizing different aspects of judgment.

questions.question: A parent is teaching their children about the importance of following God's statutes. What does Ezekiel 5 say about a nation that multiplies but does not keep God's judgments?
options: God will execute judgments and not spare them
They will prosper and be blessed
They will be ignored by God
They will be rewarded with peace
questions.correctAnswer: God will execute judgments and not spare them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:7-11 warns that multiplying without obedience leads to God’s judgments, diminishing, and no sparing or pity due to defiling His sanctuary.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility can a believer learn from Ezekiel 5 regarding pride and abominations?
options: Pride and abominations provoke God's unique and severe judgments
Pride is rewarded by God
Abominations have no spiritual consequences
God overlooks sins of pride
questions.correctAnswer: Pride and abominations provoke God's unique and severe judgments
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:8-9 reveals that because of abominations, God will do unprecedented judgments, showing the serious consequences of prideful rebellion.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 5 guide believers to handle trials such as famine and pestilence?
options: Recognize them as part of God's judgments and seek His mercy
Ignore them and continue as if nothing happened
Blame others without self-reflection
Give up on faith
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize them as part of God's judgments and seek His mercy
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:12, 16-17 describe famine, pestilence, and sword as part of God's executing judgment, implying believers should respond with repentance and humility.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 5, God sets Jerusalem in the midst of nations to bless it without requiring obedience.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:5-6 states Jerusalem was set in the midst of nations, but it changed God's judgments into wickedness and refused His statutes, leading to judgment, not unearned blessing.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 5 teaches that God's anger and fury will ultimately be accomplished for His people to understand His zeal.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:13 explains that God's anger and fury will be accomplished so that His people will know the Lord has spoken in zeal, indicating a purpose in discipline.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 5 says a third part of the people will die by _______, a third by _______, and a third will be scattered.
options: pestilence and famine; sword
water; fire
judgment; mercy
peace; war
questions.correctAnswer: pestilence and famine; sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:12 clearly states one third die by pestilence and famine, another third by the sword, and the last third scattered by the wind.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 5 teach about the importance of integrity and faithfulness in God's house?
options: Defiling God's sanctuary leads to severe judgment and diminution
Integrity in God's house is unimportant
God overlooks unfaithfulness in His house
God rewards those who defile His sanctuary
questions.correctAnswer: Defiling God's sanctuary leads to severe judgment and diminution
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:11 states that because Jerusalem defiled God's sanctuary with abominations, God will diminish and not spare them, emphasizing faithfulness in holiness.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with perseverance through trials. What does Ezekiel 5 imply about enduring God’s judgment and hope for restoration?
options: God’s judgment is purposeful and will result in knowledge of His word
Trials mean God has abandoned them entirely
Judgment has no connection to eventual restoration
Endurance is meaningless
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment is purposeful and will result in knowledge of His word
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:13 explains that after God accomplishes His fury, the people will know the Lord has spoken, indicating judgment leads to revelation and opportunity for restoration.

questions.question: What practical guidance does Ezekiel 5 offer about being a witness to the nations?
options: Judgments on Israel will be a reproach and astonishment to surrounding nations
Israel’s actions have no effect on other nations
God hides His dealings from other nations
The nations will always support Israel regardless of behavior
questions.correctAnswer: Judgments on Israel will be a reproach and astonishment to surrounding nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:14-15 shows that God will make Jerusalem a reproach and taunt, an instruction and astonishment to the nations, indicating the witness impact of Israel’s obedience or disobedience.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 5 illustrate the consequences of refusing God’s judgments and statutes in family and community life?
options: It results in extreme breakdown including parents eating children and scattering of the remnant
It leads to harmonious family life
God ignores family disobedience
Refusing God’s laws has no effect on community
questions.correctAnswer: It results in extreme breakdown including parents eating children and scattering of the remnant
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:10 warns of horrifying consequences like fathers eating sons and sons eating fathers, and scattering the remnant due to disobedience, showing societal collapse.

questions.question: When a believer faces temptation to compromise on holiness, what does Ezekiel 5 teach about consequences of defiling the sanctuary?
options: God will diminish and have no pity on those who defile His sanctuary
God will overlook defilement
Defilement leads to immediate reward
God encourages compromise
questions.correctAnswer: God will diminish and have no pity on those who defile His sanctuary
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:11 states that because of defiling the sanctuary with abominations, God will diminish and not spare or have pity, emphasizing holiness’s importance.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 5 encourage believers to approach their personal devotion and prayer in times of national crisis?
options: Recognizing God's judgments as calls to repentance and seeking His comfort
Ignoring national crises in personal devotion
Blaming others without self-examination
Giving up on prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Recognizing God's judgments as calls to repentance and seeking His comfort
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:13 shows God’s anger accomplished so that they know the Lord has spoken in zeal, implying prayerful repentance and seeking God’s comfort in trials is essential.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 5.

questions.question: What symbolic action does God command Ezekiel to perform with a sharp knife and a barber's razor in Ezekiel 5?
options: Cut his hair and beard and divide it by weighing
Carve a wooden idol
Write the law on a stone tablet
Anoint the people with oil
questions.correctAnswer: Cut his hair and beard and divide it by weighing
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:1 instructs Ezekiel to use a sharp knife and a barber's razor to pass upon his head and beard, then weigh and divide the hair as a symbolic act.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 5:2, what happens to the divided hair?
options: A third is burned, a third is cut with a knife, and a third is scattered in the wind
All is burned in the fire
All is buried under the altar
All is given to the poor
questions.correctAnswer: A third is burned, a third is cut with a knife, and a third is scattered in the wind
questions.explanation: Verse 2 details the division of hair into three parts with distinct fates: burning, striking with a knife, and scattering in the wind.

questions.question: What is the significance of binding a few hairs in Ezekiel's skirts as mentioned in Ezekiel 5:3?
options: It symbolizes captivity of a remnant
It represents cleansing from sin
It shows the anointing of priests
It is a sign of mourning
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes captivity of a remnant
questions.explanation: Verse 3 indicates some hairs are bound in Ezekiel’s skirts, symbolizing a small group taken into captivity amid judgment.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 5:5 describe the position of Jerusalem among nations?
options: Set in the midst of the nations and countries around her
Hidden among the mountains
Secluded in a desert
At the edge of the sea
questions.correctAnswer: Set in the midst of the nations and countries around her
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states that Jerusalem is set in the midst of surrounding nations, emphasizing its central and exposed position.

questions.question: What is Jerusalem accused of in Ezekiel 5:6?
options: Changing God's judgments into wickedness more than surrounding nations
Being a city of peace
Following all God's statutes perfectly
Welcoming strangers
questions.correctAnswer: Changing God's judgments into wickedness more than surrounding nations
questions.explanation: Verse 6 explains that Jerusalem corrupted God's judgments and statutes more than the neighboring nations by refusing to walk in them.

questions.question: What reason does God give in Ezekiel 5:7 for His judgment against Jerusalem?
options: Because they multiplied more than the nations but did not keep God's statutes or judgments
Because they built many altars
Because they were oppressed by foreign kings
Because they neglected the temple repairs
questions.correctAnswer: Because they multiplied more than the nations but did not keep God's statutes or judgments
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states judgment is due to their population increase without obedience to God's laws, setting them apart negatively.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 5:10, what horrific imagery is used to describe the judgment upon the people?
options: Fathers eating sons and sons eating fathers
Serpents crawling through the city
The sun turning to darkness
Rivers turning to blood
questions.correctAnswer: Fathers eating sons and sons eating fathers
questions.explanation: Verse 10 describes a gruesome famine scenario where cannibalism occurs as a form of divine judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 5:11 states that God will have mercy and spare Jerusalem despite their abominations.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5:11 declares God will diminish Jerusalem and will not spare or have pity because of their defilement and abominations.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 5:12 states that a third part of the people will die by _______, a third by _______, and a third will be scattered by the _______.
options: pestilence and famine; sword; winds
fire; flood; earth
starvation; sword; sea
plague; captivity; sun
questions.correctAnswer: pestilence and famine; sword; winds
questions.explanation: Verse 12 specifies the division of judgment with pestilence and famine, sword, and scattering by winds as the means of destruction.

questions.question: What is the purpose of God's fury being accomplished in Jerusalem as stated in Ezekiel 5:13?
options: So that they may know the LORD has spoken with zeal
To bring peace to the nations
To establish a new temple
To reward the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: So that they may know the LORD has spoken with zeal
questions.explanation: Verse 13 emphasizes that God's fury is fulfilled to show His zeal and confirm His word to the people.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 5:14, how will Jerusalem be perceived among the nations after the judgment?
options: As a waste and reproach
As a great kingdom
As a city of hope
As a place of refuge
questions.correctAnswer: As a waste and reproach
questions.explanation: Verse 14 states that Jerusalem will become a waste and reproach among the neighboring nations, reflecting disgrace.

questions.question: What function does Ezekiel 5:15 assign to the judgments upon Jerusalem in relation to surrounding nations?
options: A reproach, taunt, instruction, and astonishment
A blessing and encouragement
A secret to be kept
An example of mercy
questions.correctAnswer: A reproach, taunt, instruction, and astonishment
questions.explanation: Verse 15 describes the judgment as serving multiple roles: reproach, taunt, instruction, and astonishment for surrounding nations.

questions.question: What are the 'evil arrows of famine' mentioned in Ezekiel 5:16 symbolic of?
options: Divine destruction and judgment
Healing and restoration
Peace and prosperity
Human rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: Divine destruction and judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 16 metaphorically describes famine as 'evil arrows' sent by God to destroy Jerusalem, symbolizing divine judgment.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 5:17, which calamities are listed as coming upon Jerusalem?
options: Famine, evil beasts, pestilence, blood, and sword
Rain, sunshine, crops, and peace
Fire, flood, earthquake, and wind
Exile, slavery, drought, and famine
questions.correctAnswer: Famine, evil beasts, pestilence, blood, and sword
questions.explanation: Verse 17 lists a series of calamities including famine, wild beasts, pestilence, bloodshed, and sword as judgments upon Jerusalem.

questions.question: How does the use of hair in Ezekiel 5 function as a typological symbol in prophetic literature?
options: It symbolizes the fate of the people divided into death, captivity, and dispersion
It represents the anointing of kings
It denotes purity and holiness
It signifies the growth of the nation
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the fate of the people divided into death, captivity, and dispersion
questions.explanation: The cutting and dividing of hair in Ezekiel 5 is a typological symbol foreshadowing the division of Jerusalem’s people into death, captivity, and diaspora.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What symbolic act is Ezekiel commanded to perform involving a sharp knife and a barber's razor?
options: Pass it upon his head and beard and divide the hair
Cut off his hair and bury it in the city
Anoint his head and beard with oil
Weave the hair into a garment
questions.correctAnswer: Pass it upon his head and beard and divide the hair
questions.explanation: Ezekiel is instructed to take a sharp knife and a barber's razor to pass upon his head and beard and then divide the hair, symbolizing judgment and division among the people (Ezekiel 5:1). This act echoes prophetic symbolism in Isaiah 3:24 and Jeremiah 7:29, where hair cutting represents judgment and purification.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 5, how is the divided hair to be treated?
options: One third burned in the city, one third smitten with a knife, one third scattered in the wind
All burned outside the city
All buried in the temple court
One third given to the poor, one third to priests, one third to prophets
questions.correctAnswer: One third burned in the city, one third smitten with a knife, one third scattered in the wind
questions.explanation: The divided hair is to be treated in three ways: a third burned in the city, a third smitten with a knife, and a third scattered in the wind, symbolizing different aspects of judgment and dispersion (Ezekiel 5:2). This foreshadows the judgment and scattering found in Deuteronomy 28:32 and Jeremiah 9:16.

questions.question: What does God declare Jerusalem has done in regard to His judgments and statutes?
options: Changed His judgments into wickedness more than the nations
Obeyed His statutes perfectly
Ignored the nations and followed their customs
Kept His laws more faithfully than other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Changed His judgments into wickedness more than the nations
questions.explanation: Jerusalem is charged with changing God's judgments into wickedness more than the surrounding nations and refusing to walk in His statutes (Ezekiel 5:6). This reflects the persistent rebellion seen in Israel throughout scripture (e.g., Isaiah 1:4, Psalm 106:34-39, Hosea 4:6).

questions.question: What reason does God give for executing unprecedented judgments on Jerusalem?
options: Because of all her abominations
Because the people were righteous
Because she was a model city
Because of the neighboring nations' sins
questions.correctAnswer: Because of all her abominations
questions.explanation: God declares He will do what He has never done before because of the abominations committed by Jerusalem (Ezekiel 5:9). This underscores God's holiness and intolerance of sin (Leviticus 18:24-30, Habakkuk 1:13, Romans 1:18).

questions.question: What horrific judgment is described involving family members in Jerusalem?
options: Fathers shall eat their sons and sons their fathers
Families shall be spared from judgment
Sons shall be exiled but fathers remain
Families will be reunited in peace
questions.correctAnswer: Fathers shall eat their sons and sons their fathers
questions.explanation: God foretells a cannibalistic judgment where family members will consume each other due to extreme famine and siege (Ezekiel 5:10). This severe judgment echoes warnings in 2 Kings 6:28-29 and Lamentations 4:10, illustrating the consequences of sin and God's wrath.

questions.question: What consequence is declared for defiling God's sanctuary with detestable things?
options: Diminishing of the people without pity or mercy
Immediate forgiveness and restoration
Exile with eventual restoration
Protection from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Diminishing of the people without pity or mercy
questions.explanation: Because Jerusalem defiled God's sanctuary with abominations, God states He will diminish them and not spare or pity them (Ezekiel 5:11). This reflects God's holiness and justice, consistent with passages like Leviticus 20:3, Hebrews 10:26-31, and Nahum 1:2-3.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 5, how are the people of Jerusalem to be divided in judgment?
options: One third die by pestilence and famine, one third by sword, one third scattered
All will perish by fire
Half will be saved and half destroyed
One third will repopulate the city
questions.correctAnswer: One third die by pestilence and famine, one third by sword, one third scattered
questions.explanation: God declares a division of judgment: a third will die from pestilence and famine, a third by the sword, and a third will be scattered into the winds (Ezekiel 5:12). This reflects God's sovereign judgment and is consistent with other biblical judgments such as in Jeremiah 24:10 and Zechariah 13:8-9.

questions.question: What is the ultimate purpose behind God's execution of His fury and judgments upon Jerusalem?
options: So that they know the LORD has spoken in zeal
To completely annihilate all survivors without purpose
To punish eternally without hope
To show mercy regardless of their actions
questions.correctAnswer: So that they know the LORD has spoken in zeal
questions.explanation: God states His fury and judgments are to be accomplished so that the people will know the LORD has spoken with zeal and fulfilled His word (Ezekiel 5:13). This emphasizes God’s faithfulness to His word, as seen in Deuteronomy 32:41-43, Isaiah 59:16, and Romans 9:22-23.

questions.question: How will Jerusalem be regarded among the nations as a result of God's judgment?
options: As a waste and reproach, an astonishment and taunt
As a beacon of hope and restoration
As a hidden city protected by God
As a place of peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: As a waste and reproach, an astonishment and taunt
questions.explanation: The city will be made waste and a reproach among surrounding nations, becoming a taunt and astonishment due to God's judgments (Ezekiel 5:14-15). This judgment serves as a warning and lesson, paralleling narratives in Lamentations 2:15 and Ezekiel 36:20-21.

questions.question: What specific instruments of destruction does God mention He will send upon Jerusalem?
options: Evil arrows of famine, evil beasts, pestilence, and the sword
Floodwaters and earthquakes
Fire from heaven and hailstones
Locusts and darkness
questions.correctAnswer: Evil arrows of famine, evil beasts, pestilence, and the sword
questions.explanation: God describes sending evil arrows of famine, evil beasts, pestilence, and the sword as instruments of destruction upon Jerusalem (Ezekiel 5:16-17). These judgments align with the plagues and divine punishments in Exodus 9, Deuteronomy 28, and Revelation 6.

questions.question: What does the staff of bread symbolize in Ezekiel 5?
options: Provision and sustenance which God will break to increase famine
A scepter of royal authority
A symbol of healing and restoration
An instrument of peace
questions.correctAnswer: Provision and sustenance which God will break to increase famine
questions.explanation: The staff of bread symbolizes provision and sustenance, which God will break to bring increased famine upon the people (Ezekiel 5:16). This metaphor is consistent with prophets like Isaiah 3:1-3 and Amos 8:11, illustrating God's control over life-sustaining resources.

questions.question: Who is the recipient of Ezekiel's prophetic symbolic actions in chapter 5?
options: The son of man (Ezekiel himself)
The priests of Israel
King Zedekiah
The elders of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The son of man (Ezekiel himself)
questions.explanation: God addresses Ezekiel as 'son of man,' instructing him to perform symbolic acts representing judgment (Ezekiel 5:1). This title underscores Ezekiel’s role as a human prophet mediating God's message, paralleling Daniel 7:13-14 and the Messianic title in John 1:51.

questions.question: What theological truth about God's justice and mercy is revealed by the judgments described in Ezekiel 5?
options: God's justice demands severe judgment for persistent sin, but it aims to lead to knowledge of His holiness
God is indifferent to sin and allows it without consequence
God only punishes the innocent
God’s mercy excludes justice
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice demands severe judgment for persistent sin, but it aims to lead to knowledge of His holiness
questions.explanation: The chapter reveals God's holiness and justice manifest in severe judgments due to persistent sin, yet the purpose is corrective—to make the people know He is the LORD (Ezekiel 5:13, 5:8). This is consistent with Romans 11:22, Hebrews 12:6, and Exodus 34:6-7.

questions.question: What does the scattering of a third part of the people symbolize in Ezekiel 5?
options: Dispersion among nations as a consequence of judgment
A voluntary pilgrimage to the Promised Land
A sign of God's favor and protection
A gathering of all tribes to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Dispersion among nations as a consequence of judgment
questions.explanation: The scattering of a third part symbolizes exile and dispersion among nations, a judgment for disobedience (Ezekiel 5:2, 5:12). This motif is found throughout Israel’s history, such as in Deuteronomy 28:64, Nehemiah 1:8, and Acts 8:1.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is prominently displayed through the judgments in Ezekiel 5?
options: God's holiness and zeal against sin
God's passivity and indifference
God's forgetfulness of sin
God's approval of rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: God's holiness and zeal against sin
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 5 shows God's holiness and zeal, as He executes judgments due to abominations, emphasizing His intolerance of sin (Ezekiel 5:13). This matches teachings in Isaiah 6:3, Nahum 1:2-3, and 1 Peter 1:16.
